requirement:
Art. 12: Record- Keeping

Definitions
(Art. 3(23)) ‘substantial modification’ means a change to an AI system after its placing on the market or putting into service which is not foreseen or planned in the initial conformity assessment carried out by the provider and as a result of which the
compliance of the AI system with the requirements set out in Chapter III, Section 2 is affected or results in a modification to the intended purpose for which the AI system has been assessed.

Trasversal Questions

rows.Compliance checklist: ●       1. The high-risk AI system technically allows for the automatic recording of events (logs) over its own lifetime.

_children.Guiding Questions: ●12.1.1     Which system events are captured automatically (i.e., API calls, model inferences, error conditions)?
○     Are there any system events that are not captured automatically? If so, why?
●12.1.2     What is the level of granularity decided for the system logging? (i.e., metadata only or full payload)?
●12.1.3     Has a logging standardized format been defined to ensure consistency?

●12.1.4     Is the logging of contextual metadata (timestamps, model version, pipeline stage) enough to allow for a full reconstruction of each event and possible chain of events as required by Art.20?
●12.1.5     How will the logs be stored (e.g. on-premise, cloud storage)?
●12.1.6     Is there a detection system to prevent unauthorized modification or deletion of log entries according to the storage environment? Describe it and justify its efficacy.
●12.1.7     Is there a detection system to alert on any attempt to tamper with the logging system?
○     Did you define log patterns or anomalies that should trigger automated alerts?
○     How will alert notifications be routed (i.e., to on-call engineers, compliance officers) and tracked to resolution?
●12.1.8     How are durability and scalability of the logging storage faced through the design phase and management in time?
●12.1.9     Are access rights and roles defined to specify who (users and/or systems) can read, query, or export logs?
●12.1.10     Is there an expected performance impact of logging?
○     If yes, which strategies will you employ to minimize overhead without losing critical system events?
●12.1.11     Are the logs indexed in order to allow for search in case of incident investigation, audit or debugging?
●12.1.12     Do you integrate any real-time monitoring system for the event logs?
○     If yes, does it consider meta-data or the log content itself? Justify your choice ensuring there is no significant loss of information taht could impact the efficacy of the monitoring.
●12.1.13     Do you integrate tools or dashboards to analyze historical data of the system logs?
○     If yes, does it consider meta-data or the log content itself? Justify your choice ensuring there is no significant loss of information taht could impact the efficacy of the monitoring.
●12.1.14 Have you established an internal or third-party audit process for the logging system to verify completeness and compliance?
○          If yes, have you also defined the time frequency of such audits?

●12.1.15     Do you generate reports to demonstrate to regulators that logs are collected and stored correctly (e.g. protected in terms of cybersecurity, compliant with GDPR)? If yes, how are such reports generated?
●12.1.16     Have you defined a process that governs over possible updates of the log schema as new features (or regulations) emerge?
○     If yes, how do you ensure backward compatibility so that past logs remain consistent with the new schema?

rows.Compliance checklist: ●       2(a). The high-risk system records events (logs) relevant to identify situations in which the system may present a risk (Art. 79(1)) or has undergone a substantial modification (Art. 3(23)), with the goal of ensuring a level of traceability of the functioning of a high-risk AI system that is appropriate to its intended purpose.

_children.Guiding Questions: ●12.2.a.1     What types of system outputs or patterns do you treat as indicators that the system might be presenting a risk (e.g., unusually high false-negative rates in candidate screening, repeated demographic bias flags, error rates above a predefined threshold, or significant deviations from expected values)?
○     [The above question presumes that each point of the example list is defined and/or can be measured and/or can be tracked in a meaningful way; examples are the following subquestions:]
○     What are the numerical thresholds for a “risk-presenting” event triggering a log entry? (i.e., confidence-score < x, false-positive rate > y)

○    Do you log every instance of a borderline decision, and if so, which specific cases are included (e.g., a candidate ranked just below a cutoff)? Or do you instead log only aggregate anomaly spikes over time (e.g., recurring spikes in error rates)?

●12.2.a.3     When defining logging triggers, how do you capture the distinction between the system’s intended purpose (Art. 3(12)) and reasonably foreseeable misuse (Art. 3(13))? For example, if a recruitment AI system is applied outside its validated demographic scope, is this treated and logged as a misuse event?
○     Which specific misuse scenarios have you identified for your system, and how are these scenarios monitored and logged?

●12.2.a.4     Is the granularity of logs defined in such a way that it is possible to reconstruct whether a given decision was within the system’s intended use? (i.e., logging that the candidate’s origin was outside the originally approved demographic).

●12.2.a.5     For each flagged risk event, which contextual attributes do you record to allow a retrospective “root-cause” analysis? (i.e., input snapshot, model version, pipeline steps, timestamp, user or service ID that invoked the decision, GPT in-context learned snapshot up to the risk event)

●12.2.a.6     How do you log instances where the system is used in ways that deviate from its normal or expected use? (For example, if a recruitment AI system designed for screening engineer-level candidates is applied to executive-level profiles.)
●12.2.a.7     Once a risk-presenting event is logged, who must be notified?
●12.2.a.8     Did you define a priority hierarchy among the notified persons (e.g. first the provider then the recruiters)?
●12.2.a.9     Which criteria trigger an immediate real-time alert versus a periodic report?
●12.2.a.10     How should alerts be routed (i.e., email, ticketing, SMS to on-call engineer)?
●12.2.a.11     What downstream workflows must be invoked once a risk log is created? (i.e. automatic freeze of new decisions pending human review)

●12.2.a.12     Which system changes do you classify as non-substantial modifications, meaning they do not alter the intended purpose or affect compliance with Chapter III Section 2 requirements? (i.e., accuracy and fairness assessment metrics remain within the bounds approved during initial conformity assessment)

●12.2.a.13     Which system modifications would you classify as falling outside the scope of pre-approved behaviours, and therefore potentially count as substantial modifications (e.g., replacing the underlying GPT model architecture with a new version)?

●12.2.a.14     How do you distinguish “configuration modifications” (i.e., hyperparameter tuning with pre-approved ranges) from “substantial modifications"? What metadata do you record to prove that a modification was within allowable bounds?

●12.2.a.15     Do you have rules in place to detect at run-time when updates or changes to system components (e.g., pipeline packages, libraries, or other dependencies) qualify as substantial modifications?

●12.2.a.16     For a given substantial modification, which information is logged to ensure traceability? A non-exhaustive list should consider including: “modification” related information (i.e., switch to new inference engine); “versioning” related information (i.e., previous model -> new model version, pipeline code commit, if applicable pipeline container images); timestamps of activation of the modification; reason and/or justification for the modification (i.e., performance drift detected, feature engineering update); operator/actor who initiated the modification; affected components of the change (pipeline components, decision logics).

●12.2.a.18    After a modification, which checks or automated tests must pass to demonstrate that the system continues to meet Chapter III, Section 2 requirements? (For example, bias audits, robustness tests, or accuracy benchmarks.)
●12.2.a.19     How do logs capture the results of such checks? (i.e., pass/fail, details, test metrics)
●12.2.a.20     Once a modification is logged as substantial, is there an automated process that ensures that the AI product is flagged for a new conformity assessment?

○          Is such a log entry linked to an internal/external audit ticket so that the compliance team can demonstrate traceability from the “modification event” to “audit outcome”? (i.e. AI version -> substantial change log -> new conformity assessment documents?)
●12.2.a.22 Once a modification event is logged, who is notified and who is authorized to see it? In case the modification is deeemed as substantial, who is notified?

●12.2.a.23     How do you ensure that logs of risk-presenting events are fed back into system development and design improvements? For instance, if a specific model version consistently triggers risk flags, how are these logged insights transferred to and acted upon by the development team?
○         Which governance process ensures that logged risks systematically inform future design choices?
●12.2.a.24     If you willingly perform a substantial modification, how do you ensure that this event is logged? Which information do you log? For instance:
○     How do you record who initiated and approved the modification?
○     How do you capture the exact time and date of the modification?
○    How do you retain both the state of the system before the modification and the state after it?
○    How do you document which components of the system were altered and in what way?
○   How do you guarantee that these logs are preserved in a tamper-evident and auditable format?
●12.2.a.25     If the substantial modifications refer to pre-allowed range of hyperparameters how can you trace those values in real-time thanks to the logs?

rows.Compliance checklist: ●       2(b). The high-risk system records events (logs) relevant for facilitating the post-market monitoring referred to in Art. 72.

_children.Guiding Questions: ●12.2.b.1     Which performance metrics (e.g., accuracy, precision, recall, demographic parity gaps) do you track to demonstrate ongoing compliance with Chapter III, Section 2?
●12.2.b.2     How do you log the indicators that are specific to each regulatory requirement (bias mitigation, robustness, transparency)?

●12.2.b.3     Does your logging system track any documents or relevant data that deployers (i.e., HR teams) might supply to feed post-market monitoring? (e.g., candidate appeals, adverse outcomes reported)

●12.2.b.4     Have you codified a “post-market monitoring plan” for logs that explicitly include: i) Data sources (deployer feedback, in-product metrics), ii) collection frequency (i.e., real-time vs daily batch) and iii) analysis pipeline (e.g., automated drift detection scripts)?

○     For each element of the post-market monitoring plan, how do you ensure that its execution is reflected in the logs? For example, if the plan includes a daily score-alignment audit, do the logs show that the audit was performed and what its results were?
●12.2.b.5     How do you record the eventual updates of the post-market monitoring plan?
●12.2.b.6    What metadata is logged to show that at any point in time, a specific version of the post-market plan was in effect?
●12.2.b.7     Who (role/title) is responsible for maintaining the post-market monitoring plan?
●12.2.b.8     How is accountability divided between the provider and the deployer (HR, IT) for collecting and analysing the logs referring to the post-market monitoring?
●12.2.b.9     How do insights from log analyses (e.g., emerging bias patterns in specific job categories) feed back into updates of the post-market monitoring plan itself?

●12.2.b.10    What technical measures in your logging system ensure that revisions of the post-market monitoring plan are recorded in a way that is protected from unauthorized change, so that the timing and content of each revision can be reliably verified during an audit?

●12.2.b.11     Is your post-market monitoring system integrated with existing logging frameworks, and if so, how do you ensure that the fields in your logs correspond to the required template elements of those frameworks?

rows.Compliance checklist: ●       2(c). The high-risk system records events (logs) relevant for monitoring the operation of high-risk AI systems referred to in Art.26(5). [identify risk situations, record suspensions, document notifications of serious incidents]

_children.Guiding Questions: ●12.2.c.1     How do you verify that each operation of the system (e.g., candidate screening run, hyperparameter change) is executed according to the published Instructions for Use required by Art.13?
●12.2.c.2     How is a deployer’s decision to suspend the AI system logged?

●12.2.c.3     What minimum information must be recorded to show that “without undue delay” use was suspended once a risk was identified? (i.e., time elapsed between first risk-flag log and suspension log)
●12.2.c.4     Which confirmation or acknowledgment is associated with suspension, and how is that captured?
●12.2.c.5     What log entries record the act of “informing the provider or distributor and the relevant market surveillance authority without undue delay”?
●12.2.c.6     What constitutes a “serious incident” in your specific recruitment application context? Do they have a specific logging template and alert system?

●12.2.c.7     When you notify the provider and the market surveillance authority about a suspension or a serious incident, how do you log that the notification was successfully delivered and acknowledged, and how do you record any follow-up actions if the first attempt at contact fails?

●12.2.c.8     When the criteria for a serious incident are met, what additional fields do you log (for example, incident ID, affected job category, number of impacted candidates, severity rating) to demonstrate compliance with Article 73 timelines?

●12.2.c.9     When a serious incident is detected, how do you log the point at which you first identified a possible causal link between the system and the incident, and how do you then log the reasoning and evidence that led to the conclusion that a causal link is established or likely?
●12.2.c.10     How do your logs capture the severity and nature of each incident, so that both immediate impact and systemic implications can be assessed later?
●12.2.c.11     After a serious incident log is created, which events record the subsequent “investigation” steps (e.g. analysis runs, interviews, risk assessments)?

●12.2.c.12  During the investigation of a serious incident, how do you log that evidence (such as raw logs, datasets, or model snapshots) has been preserved without alteration before notifying authorities?
●12.2.c.13     When a corrective action is implemented in response to a serious incident, do you capture it in the logs so that auditing is ensured?

rows.Compliance checklist: Art. 12 (3) does not apply as the system in analysis is not referred to in point 1 (a) of annex III (remote biometric identification systems).

_children.Guiding Questions: If the AI system has been developed by integrating GPAI models, what transparency measures have been adopted, taking into account the specific characteristics of such models? What technical measures and contractual safeguards have been put in place?
